head.title: To End the Conflict in Africa

hedline.hl1: To End the Conflict in Africa

abstract.p: Alison Des Forges letter on Makau Mutua's Aug 30 article opposes partition of Tutsi and Hutu in Rwanda and Burundi

block.p: Makau Mutua (Op-Ed, Aug. 30) proposes ending war in Rwanda and Burundi by creating two states, one Hutu and one Tutsi. He says ''most ordinary Africans'' agree. But in two years of negotiations to end the Burundian war, none of the 19 participants backed partition.

Why not? Because Burundi, like Rwanda, is a centuries-old state encompassing Hutu and Tutsi who share a common language, culture and religion. The struggle is indeed about power, but it also pits Tutsi against Tutsi and Hutu against Hutu. Sometimes Hutu and Tutsi from one region unite against others.

Makau Mutua (Op-Ed, Aug. 30) proposes ending war in Rwanda and Burundi by creating two states, one Hutu and one Tutsi. He says ''most ordinary Africans'' agree. But in two years of negotiations to end the Burundian war, none of the 19 participants backed partition.

Why not? Because Burundi, like Rwanda, is a centuries-old state encompassing Hutu and Tutsi who share a common language, culture and religion. The struggle is indeed about power, but it also pits Tutsi against Tutsi and Hutu against Hutu. Sometimes Hutu and Tutsi from one region unite against others.
Monoethnic states might just redefine the conflict. Burundian Hutu killed hundreds of Rwandan Hutu last February and Burundian Tutsi for years discriminated against Rwandan Tutsi in their country.
Peace in central Africa demands new attitudes, not new maps.
The writer is a consultant for Human Rights Watch, Africa.
